perturbation.original_text: A Party will have ten (10) days to provide adequate assurances of performance to the other Party in a form acceptable to the other Party in its good faith discretion.
perturbation.changed_text: A Party will have two (2) days to provide adequate assurances of performance to the other Party in a form acceptable to the other Party in its good faith discretion.
perturbation.explanation: Modifying the timeframe for providing adequate assurances of performance from ten (10) days to two (2) days creates a potential inconsistency with Section 2-609 of the Illinois Uniform Commercial Code, which requires a reasonable time to provide adequate assurance. Two days may not be considered a reasonable time, particularly for complex matters, potentially violating the UCC.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Section 2-609 of the Illinois Uniform Commercial Code

perturbation.original_text: An insuring Party must deliver the following written evidence of the required insurance coverage to the other Party (Attention: Risk Management), or its designated insurance monitoring service, within ten (10) of written request and at least thirty (30) days in advance of the expiration of a then current policy term (if a declaration or endorsement is not available from an insurer at the time requested or required, an insuring Party will provide them as soon as the declaration or endorsement is available from the insurer):
perturbation.changed_text: An insuring Party must deliver the following written evidence of the required insurance coverage to the other Party (Attention: Risk Management), or its designated insurance monitoring service, within five (5) of written request and at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the expiration of a then current policy term (if a declaration or endorsement is not available from an insurer at the time requested or required, an insuring Party will provide them as soon as the declaration or endorsement is available from the insurer):
perturbation.explanation: Shortening the timeframe for providing insurance documentation from ten (10) to five (5) days upon written request and from thirty (30) to fifteen (15) days before policy expiration can be problematic. Depending on the complexity of the insurance requirements and the responsiveness of the insurer, this reduced timeframe may not provide sufficient time to gather and submit the necessary documents, particularly the declaration pages of insurance policy, potentially conflicting with what is considered a reasonable timeframe under general contract law principles.

perturbation.original_text: The rights and obligations of the Parties under this Section with regards to disclosed Confidential Information will continue: (1) Until the earlier of (i) sixty (60) months from the date of disclosure to a Receiving Party or (ii) the date such information ceases to be considered Confidential Information under this Agreement, for Confidential Information that is not a trade secret of a Disclosing Party under Applicable Law; and (2) Until Confidential Information that is a trade secret of a Disclosing Party under Applicable Law ceases to be a trade secret of the Disclosing Party under Applicable Law.
perturbation.changed_text: The rights and obligations of the Parties under this Section with regards to disclosed Confidential Information will continue: (1) Until the earlier of (i) twelve (12) months from the date of disclosure to a Receiving Party or (ii) the date such information ceases to be considered Confidential Information under this Agreement, for Confidential Information that is not a trade secret of a Disclosing Party under Applicable Law; and (2) Until Confidential Information that is a trade secret of a Disclosing Party under Applicable Law ceases to be a trade secret of the Disclosing Party under Applicable Law.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period for non-trade secret confidential information from sixty (60) months (5 years) to twelve (12) months (1 year) may be insufficient to adequately protect sensitive business information in Illinois. Illinois courts generally enforce confidentiality agreements, but the duration must be reasonable based on the nature of the information and the industry. A one-year period may be deemed unreasonably short for certain types of confidential business data, creating unenforceability issues.
